choices.text: The foramen ovale, rotundum and spinosum
The foramen ovale, rotundum and spinosum and foramen lacerum

questions.text: Which of the following foramina pierce the sphenoid bone?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Foramen ovale, foramen rotundum, and foramen spinosum are located within the greater wing of the sphenoid bone.

  • The sphenoid bone is a complex central skull bone that forms a part of the floor of the cranial cavity and contains several key foramina that transmit important neurovascular structures
  • The greater wing of the sphenoid extends from the sphenoid body in a lateral, superior and posterior direction. It contributes to three parts of the facial skeleton:
    • Floor of the middle cranial fossa
    • Lateral wall of the skull
    • Posterolateral wall of the orbit
  • There are three foramina present in the greater wing of the sphenoid :
    • Foramen rotundum: Located in the anterior part of the greater wing of the sphenoid, transmits the maxillary nerve (V2).
    • Foramen ovale: Found posterior and lateral to the foramen rotundum, transmits the mandibular nerve (V3), accessory meningeal artery, and lesser petrosal nerve.
    • Foramen spinosum: Located posterolateral to the foramen ovale, transmits the middle meningeal artery and meningeal branch of the mandibular nerve.
  • These foramina pierce the sphenoid bone directly, distinguishing them from adjacent structures like the foramen lacerum, which is bounded by multiple bones and not pierced by neurovascular structures.

questions.text: Which of the following bones has a process that joins with the zygomatic bone to form the zygomatic arch?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The zygomatic process of the temporal bone unites with the temporal process of the zygomatic bone to form the zygomatic arch.

  • The zygomatic arch is a bony bridge on the side of the skull formed by the articulation between:
    • The temporal process of the zygomatic bone (which projects posteriorly)
    • The zygomatic process of the temporal bone (which projects anteriorly)
  • This arch serves as the origin for the masseter muscle and is a prominent anatomical landmark.
  • It does not involve the maxilla, frontal, or sphenoid bones directly in forming the arch

Explanation of other options:

The maxillary bone (Option A) : The maxilla articulates with the zygomatic bone but does not contribute to the zygomatic arch.

The sphenoid bone (Option C) : Though the sphenoid bone articulates with the zygomatic bone via its greater wing, it does not form part of the zygomatic arch.

The frontal bone (Option D) : The frontal bone forms the lateral orbital rim and articulates with the zygomatic bone, but not the arch.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries passes through the foramen marked in the image below in a case of extradural hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked structure is foramen spinosum and the middle meningeal artery passes through foramen spinosum.

  • In cases of epidural (extradural) hemorrhage, the most commonly involved artery is the middle meningeal artery.
  • The middle meningeal artery, a branch of the maxillary artery, enters the skull through the foramen spinosum, located in the greater wing of the sphenoid.
  • It runs within the periosteal layer of the dura mater and is vulnerable to rupture in trauma. Mostly in the pterion region , leading to epidural hemorrhage.

questions.text: Which compartment and its content is correctly matched to the marked foramen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked compartment is the Anterior compartment of Jugular foramen and the content in it is inferior petrosal sinus.

The jugular foramen may be subdivided into three compartments, each with their own contents.

  • The anterior compartment transmits the inferior petrosal sinus.
  • The intermediate compartment transmits the glossopharyngeal nerve, the vagus nerve, and the accessory nerve.
  • The posterior compartment transmits the sigmoid sinus (becoming the internal jugular vein), and some meningeal branches from the occipital artery and ascending pharyngeal artery.

questions.text: Which of the following veins does not drain into the internal jugular vein (IJV)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The occipital vein drains into the external jugular vein, unlike the other veins listed which primarily drain into the internal jugular vein.

  • The internal jugular vein (IJV) is the main venous drainage of the brain, face, and neck.
  • It begins at the jugular foramen and receives tributaries including:
    • Facial vein: drains anterior face and communicates with deep facial vein and angular vein. (Option A ruled out)
    • Lingual vein: drains the tongue and floor of the mouth. (Option B ruled out)
    • Pharyngeal veins, thyroid veins, and superior middle thyroid veins also drain into the IJV.
  • The posterior division of the retromandibular vein usually joins with the posterior auricular vein to form the external jugular vein. (Option C ruled out)
  • Anterior division of the retromandibular vein joins the facial vein to drain into the IJV.
  • Most clinically significant venous return from the retromandibular vein reaches the IJV via the anterior division.
  • The occipital vein primarily drains the posterior scalp and empties into the external jugular vein, or sometimes into the vertebral venous plexus.

questions.text: Which of the following bones forms the marked foramen ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked foramen is foramen lacerum which is formed by temporal , sphenoid and occipital bones.

  • The foramen lacerum (Latin: lacerated piercing) is a triangular hole in the base of skull. It is located between 3 bones:
    • Sphenoid bone(forming the anterior border)
    • Apex of petrous part of temporal bone (forming the posterolateral border)
    • Basilar part of occipital bone (forming the posteromedial border)
  • It is the junction point of 3 sutures of the skull:
    • Petroclival (petro occipital) suture
    • Sphenopetrosal suture
    • Spheno Occipital suture

choices.text: The pterion is formed by the junction of the frontal, parietal, temporal, and occipital bones.
The anterior branch of the middle cerebral artery passes beneath the pterion.
Fracture at the pterion may lead to rupture of the middle meningeal vein, causing subdural hemorrhage.
The pterion is the thinnest part of the lateral skull, and injury here can cause an epidural hematoma due to middle meningeal artery rupture.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the pterion and related clinical anatomy is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Trauma to the pterion, the thinnest part of the skull, can rupture the middle meningeal artery, leading to an epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • The pterion is a clinically important region where four bones meet:
    • Frontal bone
    • Parietal bone
    • Greater wing of the sphenoid
    • Squamous part of the temporal bone
  • It is located on the lateral aspect of the skull and overlies the anterior division of the middle meningeal artery, a branch of the maxillary artery.
  • Because the skull is particularly thin at the pterion, trauma here can rupture the artery, leading to extradural (epidural) hematoma, classically presenting with a lucid interval followed by deterioration in consciousness , which is a surgical emergency.

Explanation of other options:

The pterion is formed by the junction of the frontal, parietal, temporal, and occipital bones (Option A) : The occipital bone is not involved in the pterion; instead, it's the sphenoid bone.

The anterior branch of the middle cerebral artery passes beneath the pterion (Option B) : The middle cerebral artery is within the subarachnoid space, not in contact with the pterion. The middle meningeal artery, a dural vessel, is the one that lies beneath the pterion.

Fracture at the pterion may lead to rupture of the middle meningeal vein, causing subdural hemorrhage (Option C) : Subdural hemorrhage involves bridging veins, and middle meningeal vein rupture more commonly causes epidural hemorrhage, along with the artery.

questions.text:
Arrange the following structures in order from lateral to medial in the cerebral hemisphere (as viewed in horizontal/transverse section)
(A) Optic nerve (B) Broca's area (C) Circle of Willis (D) Sylvian fissure
questions.solution:
Explanation:

From a lateral to medial view, Broca's area (inferior frontal gyrus) lies most laterally, followed by the Sylvian fissure, then the optic nerve in the basal forebrain, and finally the Circle of Willis at the midline base of the brain.

  • Broca's area: Located in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant (usually left) hemisphere is the most lateral in this list.
  • Sylvian fissure (lateral sulcus): Lies just medial to Broca's area and separates the frontal and temporal lobes.
  • Optic nerve: Emerges from the eyeball and travels medially toward the optic chiasm at the base of the brain.
  • Circle of Willis: Lies in the interpeduncular fossa at the midline base of the brain, surrounding the optic chiasm and hypothalamus—most medial in this list.
  • Thus, from lateral to medial:
    • Broca's area → Sylvian fissure → Optic nerve → Circle of Willis
